localized-strings.localized-string: Terms, definitions, symbols and abbreviated terms
No terms and definitions are listed in this document.

This document uses the terms defined in https://portal.ogc.org/public_ogc/directives/directives.php[OGC Policy Directive 49], which is based on the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2, Rules for the structure and drafting of International Standards. In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this document and OGC documents do not use the equivalent phrases in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2.
This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (https://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=34762[OGC 08-131r3]), also known as the 'ModSpec'. The definitions of terms such as standard, specification, requirement, and conformance test are provided in the ModSpec.
For the purposes of this document, the following additional terms and definitions apply.

The following documents are referred to in the text in such a way that some or all of their content constitutes requirements of this document. For dated references, only the edition cited applies. For undated references, the latest edition of the referenced document (including any amendments) applies.
There are no normative references in this document.

This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (https://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=34762[OGC 08-131r3]), also known as the 'ModSpec'. For the purposes of this document, the terms and definitions given in % additionally apply.

In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this document and OGC documents do not use the equivalent phrases in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2.
This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (https://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=34762[OGC 08-131r3]), also known as the 'ModSpec'. The definitions of terms such as standard, specification, requirement, and conformance test are provided in the ModSpec.
For the purposes of this document, the terms and definitions given in % and the following additionally apply.
No security considerations have been made for this document.

semantic__terms.semantic__p: No terms and definitions are listed in this document.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: This section describes the beneficiaries and benefits of representing data, including geospatial data, using semantic and graph technologies. Furthermore, a collection of use cases demonstrate how semantic and graph technologies are used together with spatial data to tackle real world problems.
The benefits of semantic and graph technologies are outlined below.
GeoSPARQL is the most common geospatial extension of SPARQL. It was accepted as an OGC standard in 2012 and revised as GeoSPARQL 1.1 in 2024.

According to the standard document, “The OGC GeoSPARQL standard supports representing and querying geospatial data on the Semantic Web. GeoSPARQL defines a vocabulary for representing geospatial data in RDF, and it defines an extension to the SPARQL query language for processing geospatial data”.
GeoSPARQL addresses the following requirements with regards to 3D.

This section provides an overview of feedback received on the current version of the GeoSPARQL standard (version 1.1) regarding 3D usage. This feedback helps to identify some of the barriers to use, and to outline requirements that have not been addressed that may encourage greater uptake.
Semantic improvement
GeoSPARQL should include ways to represent 3D data in a knowledge graph.
3D data should be included in common 3D formats and 3D data should be includable as a text literal and a file representation.
Some common formats which could be considered for inclusion are:
Semantic improvement

GeoSPARQL should include ways to represent relations between 3D geometries and relations between 3D geometries and geometries of lower dimensions. The relations should be expressable in property relations and should be queryable using SPARQL extension functions.
Semantic improvement
GeoSPARQL should include ways to represent materials and textures of 3D geometries, so that geometries can be styled accordingly. Materials include:

semantic__li.semantic__p: Colors of surfaces with light diffusion parameters
Images as textures, which are associated with surfaces of the 3D object

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Semantic improvement

GeoSPARQL should include ways to define multi-component 3D geometries, whereas each component expresses its own semantics. For example, parts of a building could have different semantics according to the function of the building components and would be classified as such in an RDF graph.
Semantic improvement

GeoSPARQL 3D should be aligned to other vocabularies and standard which currently provide 3D support in different knowledge domains. Especially alignments to ifcOWL and the X3D vocabulary would position the GeoSPARQL vocabulary as a link between these different standards.

semantic__clause.semantic__title: Extension 6: Alignments of Engineering CRS to Geospatial CRS

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Semantic improvement

GeoSPARQL 3D should provide the opportunity to align a local coordinate system in which most 3D geometries are defined with a coordinate reference. While this work might only be partially done within the scope of GeoSPARQL itself, GeoSPARQL should be aligned with the emerging Ontology CRS developments of OGC and provide necessary functions or properties to create the link.
Semantic improvement
GeoSPARQL 3D should provide the opportunity to extrude 2D geometries to 3D geometries and vice versa.

semantic__references.semantic__p: There are no normative references in this document.

semantic__dd.semantic__p: World Wide Web Consortium, RDF 1.1 Concepts and Abstract Syntax, W3C Recommendation (25 February 2014).
World Wide Web Consortium, RDF 1.1 Turtle Terse RDF Triple Language, W3C Recommendation (25 February 2014).

terms.title: Terms and definitions
terms.p: No terms and definitions are listed in this document.

clause.title: Beneficiaries and benefits
clause.p: This section describes the beneficiaries and benefits of representing data, including geospatial data, using semantic and graph technologies. Furthermore, a collection of use cases demonstrate how semantic and graph technologies are used together with spatial data to tackle real world problems.

clause.title: Benefits
clause.p: The benefits of semantic and graph technologies are outlined below.

clause.title: GeoSPARQL
clause.p: GeoSPARQL is the most common geospatial extension of SPARQL. It was accepted as an OGC standard in 2012 and revised as GeoSPARQL 1.1 in 2024.

According to the standard document, “The OGC GeoSPARQL standard supports representing and querying geospatial data on the Semantic Web. GeoSPARQL defines a vocabulary for representing geospatial data in RDF, and it defines an extension to the SPARQL query language for processing geospatial data”.

clause.title: Requirements addressed
clause.p: GeoSPARQL addresses the following requirements with regards to 3D.

clause.title: Requirements for GeoSPARQL 3D
clause.p: This section provides an overview of feedback received on the current version of the GeoSPARQL standard (version 1.1) regarding 3D usage. This feedback helps to identify some of the barriers to use, and to outline requirements that have not been addressed that may encourage greater uptake.

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL should include ways to represent 3D data in a knowledge graph.
3D data should be included in common 3D formats and 3D data should be includable as a text literal and a file representation.
Some common formats which could be considered for inclusion are:

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL should include ways to represent relations between 3D geometries and relations between 3D geometries and geometries of lower dimensions. The relations should be expressable in property relations and should be queryable using SPARQL extension functions.

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL should include ways to represent materials and textures of 3D geometries, so that geometries can be styled accordingly. Materials include:

li.p: Colors of surfaces with light diffusion parameters
Images as textures, which are associated with surfaces of the 3D object

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL should include ways to define multi-component 3D geometries, whereas each component expresses its own semantics. For example, parts of a building could have different semantics according to the function of the building components and would be classified as such in an RDF graph.

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL 3D should be aligned to other vocabularies and standard which currently provide 3D support in different knowledge domains. Especially alignments to ifcOWL and the X3D vocabulary would position the GeoSPARQL vocabulary as a link between these different standards.

clause.title: Extension 6: Alignments of Engineering CRS to Geospatial CRS

fmt-title.semx: Extension 6: Alignments of Engineering CRS to Geospatial CRS

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL 3D should provide the opportunity to align a local coordinate system in which most 3D geometries are defined with a coordinate reference. While this work might only be partially done within the scope of GeoSPARQL itself, GeoSPARQL should be aligned with the emerging Ontology CRS developments of OGC and provide necessary functions or properties to create the link.

clause.title: Category
clause.p: Semantic improvement

clause.title: Description
clause.p: GeoSPARQL 3D should provide the opportunity to extrude 2D geometries to 3D geometries and vice versa.

references.title: Normative references
references.p: There are no normative references in this document.
